timeline.bodyText:
Do we need a method with a single usage?
Will it be more suitable to inline it?
timeline.author: anton-vinogradov
anton-vinogradov

replies.bodyText: We always can be hit by GC pause, timer granulation, delays in other code. Not giving additional time to wait can lead to flaky tests. Makes sense?
replies.author: Vladsz83

timeline.bodyText:
We should wait FDT - (cutTime - lastMesssentTime) here, not full FDT.


This code will fail if we wait for 0.8 of FDT in the first case and 0.1 in the second, but everything will be fine in general.
It seems you should wait for the rest of the timeout at the first case, but for the rest of the rest it at second.
timeline.author: anton-vinogradov

replies.bodyText:
This would require us to check connection often. Like connCheckInterval = spi.failureDetectionTimeout() / 4.. Otherwise we can leave too short timeout to any message if it is being sent just before next ping: quite long time passed since the last message. Is it OK?


Didn't catch you. We do wait for rest of the rest in second case:


timeout = timeoutHelper.nextTimeoutChunk(ackTimeout0); - this is rest of the rest. Makes sense?
replies.author: Vladsz83

timeline.bodyText: what the reason to set sent time here?
timeline.author: anton-vinogradov

replies.bodyText: We’ve just initialized successful connection to next node. We just sent TcpDiscoveryHandshakeRequest message. This means: this connection is definitely ok and should not be checked right now. Also, we just sent a message. We rely on the time of last message sent and we fixate it here. Looks correct to me.
replies.author: Vladsz83

timeline.bodyText: what the reason to set sent time here?
timeline.author: anton-vinogradov

replies.bodyText: We just sent one or several pending messages. Every message can take time, also every message checks connection. We rely on the time of last sent message. We should fixate this time when do really send message. We do it in this part of code too.
replies.author: Vladsz83

timeline.author: anton-vinogradov

replies.bodyText: To increase encapsulation once we touched it. Internal usages inly, not an interface.
replies.author: Vladsz83

replies.bodyText: We shouldn't reduce visibility of methods in public API. It is highly unlikely of course that there are users calling this method directly but concealing of method is definitely a breaking change. We could target it to 3.0 version but in minor releases it is not acceptable.

magic number

We always can be hit by GC pause, timer granulation, delays in other code. Not giving additional time to wait can lead to flaky tests. Makes sense?

timeline.bodyText: Why not to call updateLastSentMessageTime method here as well?
timeline.author: sergey-chugunov-1985

replies.bodyText:
Why not to call updateLastSentMessageTime method here as well?

We hasn't successfully sent message here, we hasn't received RES_OK.
replies.author: Vladsz83

replies.bodyText: As you can see, we call updateLastSentMessageTime() after successful reading spi.readReceipt or proper TcpDiscoveryHandshakeResponse. These are the places where we are sure the message was sent and connection is OK.
replies.author: Vladsz83
